author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: Five bold predictions for NFL Week 7
summary: Week 7 of the NFL features an excellent slate of matchups, concluding with Monday Night’s NFC East battle between Washington and Philadelphia, which we may or may not have picked as our upset of the week. With that in mind, here are our five bold predictions. Ben Roethlisberger has struggled mightily in this his 14th season.

author: DeltaBravo
title: NFL Referees Association refutes claims of referee Pete Morelli bias vs. Eagles
summary: Philadelphia Eagles fans have been so loud about their distaste for referee Pete Morelli and his crew that the NFL Referees Association felt the need to put out a statement.

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Smokin' Jay? More like Fiery Jay. Cutler gets emotional, and his coach loves it
summary: Don't care? Don't think so. Jay Cutler cares very much about playing at a high level, and now there is proof that even his biggest haters can't ignore. Cutler was downright fiery Sunday in Atlanta, chopping a first down signal through the air after connecting with Jarvis Landry on a huge late conversion. The game was tied 17-17 with under five minutes left, and the Dolphins faced third-and-long at the Falcons' 29. An incompletion — or worse, a sack — would have set up a challenging field goal for Cody Parkey and left plenty of time for the Falcons to rally. There was no incompletion. Cutler connected with Landry short of the sticks, but Landry — who never lacks for emotion — broke three tackles

author: nanook
title: Redskins RB Chris Thompson says he won't let family go to Eagles game
summary: When Chris Thompson takes the field for Monday night's game against the Eagles in Philadelphia, his family won't be in attendance.  That's because the running back has asked his family not to attend the game at Lincoln Financial Field due to the hostile nature of Eagles fans. "I heard that's the one stadium you keep your family from going to," Thompson said on ESPN980. "My family will be here this week, and they were like, 'I want to come to the Philly game.' I said, 'Absolutely not, you're going to have to wait until Dallas comes around.' Because my stepdad, he's a big guy and if he starts fighting, it'll be real bad out there. I was told that right away my rookie year: Keep your family away."

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: #HeyTony: What's the first piece to fix in the Browns' mess?
summary: Tony Grossi has covered the Cleveland Browns since 1984, currently for ESPN Cleveland, and is one of 46 voters for the Pro Football Hall of Fame. Hey Tony: With the losing so deep-rooted, what's the most important piece to fix first? Roster? Coaching? Front office? Ownership? Deficiencies are everywhere. -- Ben, Wadsworth, OH Hey Tony: Is poor evaluating or sub-par system/coaching -- or both -- the reason for our draft struggles? What is first step to fix? -- Robbie, Raleigh, NC Hey Ben and Robbie: There's no question the most urgent piece to fix lies with the people in charge of the draft, the roster and the planning. The decisions made at the start of this new regime – most importantly passing

title: Jaguars' Shad Khan: Trump is 'trying to soil a league that he's jealous of'
summary: The Jaguars owner is the first to go on the record and be critical of President Trump's attacks on the NFL.

author: captainunderoos
title: NFL Super Bowl odds: Green Bay Packers fall, New England Patriots hold steady
summary: This week's games kick off on Thursday night when the Chiefs and Raiders face off -- giving Kansas City a chance to potentially boost their Super Bowl odds beyond where they already stand.

author: DeltaBravo
title: Aaron Hernandez Suffered 'a Chaotic and Horrendous Existence,' His Estate Says in New Lawsuit
summary: Aaron Hernandez Suffered 'a Chaotic and Horrendous Existence,' His Estate Says in New Lawsuit

author: DeltaBravo
title: John Fox's future with Bears more complicated than it looks on surface
summary: Two victories into the Bears season, a surprising question keeps popping up. How many games do the Bears have to win for John Fox to keep his job? The surprise implicit in the question is that Fox actually might get to stick around beyond this year. Coach as sacrificial victim is nothing new. A team loses and somebody has to pay. A team loses and loses and, depending on how long his contract is, the coach eventually has to go. There is no proportion or perspective to these things. With just nine victories in 32 games in his first two years there long has been an assumption this season is it for Fox. He's in the third year of a four-year deal. The thinking is the Bears weren't willing to eat half

author: third_watch
title: Trump and NFL at odds on how to get players to stand for anthem
summary: By Jonathan Allen NEW YORK (Reuters) - The National Football League rejected U.S. President Donald Trump's calls to punish players who kneel for the national anthem to protest racism but said on Wednesday players "should" stand and it hopes the demonstrations will stop. NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell made clear he will take a more patient approach than the one urged by the president: Rather than using discipline, the league will continue to nurture players' efforts to fight racial disparities in the criminal justice system, believing this would make the urge to protest fade. "We have about six or seven players that are involved in this protest at this point," Goodell told reporters after a two-day meeting with team owners and the players' labor union in New York City, saying he hoped that number would eventually be zero.

author: Yahoo News
title: Jerry Jones is lone rebel in group of NFL owners who can thwart progress amid anthem debate
summary: The Cowboys boss is the only owner not on message, not rowing in the same direction, and most certainly not feeling the flowery optimism. That continues to make him the wedge that invites President Donald Trump through the door and into the league’s business.
